messages.ssml: <speak>CDC has two confirmed cases of pet cats in the United States becoming sick with mild resperatory illness caused by COVID-19. SARS-CoV-2 infections have been reported in very few animals worldwide, mostly in those that had close contact with a person with COVID-19.To date, there is no evidence that pets can spread the virus to people. Until more information is known about the new coronavirus it is recommended that pets should not interact with people or animals outside the household, and people sick with COVID-19 should limit contact with animals. When possible, have another member of your household care for your animals while you are sick.</speak>

messages.speech: CDC has two confirmed cases of pet cats in the United States becoming sick with mild resperatory illness caused by COVID-19. SARS-CoV-2 infections have been reported in very few animals worldwide, mostly in those that had close contact with a person with COVID-19.To date, there is no evidence that pets can spread the virus to people. Until more information is known about the new coronavirus it is recommended that pets should not interact with people or animals outside the household, and people sick with COVID-19 should limit contact with animals. When possible, have another member of your household care for your animals while you are sick.
